body_html:
Thanks @alquraishi . On your implementation of zoneout, did you multiply the outputs by 1 - (1/d) in order to maintain the sum of the outputs the same? I tried to see if they did that in the paper and couldn't find if they did that or not.

Also, did you end up using the LSTM variant that they showed right before section 4? http://arxiv.org/pdf/1606.01305v2.pdf

I find that these elements may be crucial and could explain why they used a d of 0.05 (which is pretty low) for optimal results.
body_text:
Thanks @alquraishi . On your implementation of zoneout, did you multiply the outputs by 1 - (1/d) in order to maintain the sum of the outputs the same? I tried to see if they did that in the paper and couldn't find if they did that or not.
Also, did you end up using the LSTM variant that they showed right before section 4? http://arxiv.org/pdf/1606.01305v2.pdf
I find that these elements may be crucial and could explain why they used a d of 0.05 (which is pretty low) for optimal results.
body:
Thanks @alquraishi . On your implementation of zoneout, did you multiply the outputs by `1 - (1/d)` in order to maintain the sum of the outputs the same? I tried to see if they did that in the paper and couldn't find if they did that or not.

Also, did you end up using the LSTM variant that they showed right before section 4? http://arxiv.org/pdf/1606.01305v2.pdf

I find that these elements may be crucial and could explain why they used a d of 0.05 (which is pretty low) for optimal results.
